criteria: Understanding and Application of Grammar Conventions
Usage as a Matter of Convention
Resolution of Complex or Contested Usage Issues
descriptions: Shows no understanding of standard English grammar and usage.
Demonstrates minimal understanding of grammar conventions with frequent errors that impede comprehension.
Demonstrates a basic understanding of grammar conventions but makes several errors that occasionally confuse the meaning.
Demonstrates a satisfactory understanding of grammar conventions with some errors that do not significantly affect clarity.
Demonstrates a strong understanding of grammar conventions with only minor errors that do not affect clarity.
Demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of grammar conventions with virtually no errors, enhancing the clarity and precision of writing or speaking.
Shows no awareness that usage is a matter of convention.
Shows limited awareness that usage is a matter of convention and does not apply this understanding.
Shows some awareness that usage is a matter of convention but struggles to apply this understanding in practice.
Understands that usage is a matter of convention and can generally apply this understanding in most situations.
Clearly understands that usage is a matter of convention, and applies this understanding effectively in writing or speaking.
Demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of usage conventions, including their evolution and contested nature.
Unable to identify or resolve any complex or contested usage issues.
Identifies complex or contested usage issues but is unable to resolve them effectively.
Attempts to resolve complex or contested usage issues with limited success.
Resolves simple usage issues and attempts to resolve complex or contested issues, sometimes successfully.
Effectively resolves most complex or contested usage issues, typically using appropriate references.
Consistently and effectively resolves complex or contested usage issues, demonstrating skillful use of references.
